importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the alleged sexual assault at Gettysburg College, which occurred during the eve of winter break when few people were on campus.
The date when Ian Cleary sent the Facebook message stating 'So I raped you' to Shannon Keeler, reactivating her efforts to pursue charges.
The date when Shannon Keeler shared her experience in an Associated Press story about the reluctance of prosecutors to pursue campus sexual assault cases, which led to the indictment of Cleary.
The date when Ian Cleary was detained in Metz, France, on a vagrancy-related charge, which ultimately enabled authorities to track him down and initiate extradition proceedings.
The date when Cleary was extradited from France to Pennsylvania, marking the beginning of legal proceedings in the U.S. after years of being out of reach.
The date of the sentencing of Ian Cleary to two to four years in prison, reflecting the culmination of a long legal process spanning over a decade.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 12-year span from the original assault in 2013 to the 2025 sentencing, highlighting the long delay in justice and the impact of systemic failure in sexual assault investigations on college campuses.

The period from 2019 to 2025 during which Cleary sent the Facebook message and Keeler renewed her pursuit of justice, illustrating how public awareness and media attention played a pivotal role in reactivating legal action.

keyTakeAways: A man who sexually assaulted a college student in 2013 and sent a message saying 'So I raped you' was sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025 after being extradited from France.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, waited over a decade to seek justice, with prosecutors initially reluctant to file charges due to the passage of time and loss of evidence.
The case underscores systemic failures in campus sexual assault cases, including delayed investigations, destruction of rape kits, and lack of accountability.
Ian Cleary’s mental health history and remorse played a significant role in the judge’s decision to impose a sentence below state guidelines, despite the severity of the crime.
The case gained momentum when Keeler shared her story in an AP article in 2021, which led to renewed prosecution efforts and eventually Cleary’s extradition from France.
The message sent by Cleary as part of a 12-step program was seen by the victim as reopening traumatic wounds, symbolizing the failure of the justice system to protect survivors.

namedEntities.name: Shannon Keeler
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The victim of the 2013 sexual assault at Gettysburg College; she initiated legal action and publicly shared her experience to draw attention to systemic failures in campus sexual assault cases.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the central figure whose prolonged struggle for justice led to the eventual prosecution and sentencing of Ian Cleary, making her experience emblematic of broader issues in campus sexual assault.

namedEntities.name: Ian Cleary
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The accused man who sexually assaulted Shannon Keeler in 2013 and later sent a Facebook message stating 'So I raped you'; he was extradited from France and sentenced in 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central defendant in the case, whose actions—both the assault and the message—triggered legal and emotional consequences, illustrating the long-term impact of sexual violence and the challenges of accountability.

namedEntities.name: Gettysburg College
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The college in Pennsylvania where the sexual assault occurred in 2013 and where Cleary was a student.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It represents a typical college environment where campus sexual assault cases often face challenges in prosecution due to institutional delays and lack of support for survivors.

namedEntities.name: Kevin Hess
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The senior judge who presided over the sentencing of Ian Cleary, emphasizing the severity of the crime and the defendant’s remorse.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His ruling reflected judicial consideration of the defendant’s guilt, mental health, and remorse, shaping the final sentence below state guidelines.

namedEntities.name: Andrea Levy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Shannon Keeler’s lawyer, who expressed relief that the case was resolved despite the sentence being lower than expected.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provided legal representation and advocacy, helping to ensure the case reached trial and highlighting the importance of legal support for survivors.

namedEntities.name: John Abom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Cleary’s defense lawyer who argued that Cleary was homeless and unaware of the charges at the time of the assault.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He presented a defense based on mental health and homelessness, influencing the legal narrative and contributing to the judge’s leniency.

namedEntities.name: Brian Sinnett
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Adams County District Attorney who expressed doubt about Cleary’s ability to evade justice but could not prove he was on the run.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represented the prosecutorial perspective, emphasizing that authorities were unable to track Cleary down until his arrest in France.

namedEntities.name: Associated Press
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The news outlet that published Keeler’s story in 2021, which contributed to renewed prosecution efforts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article exposed the reluctance of prosecutors to pursue campus sex crimes, prompting public and legal attention that led to Cleary’s indictment.

namedEntities.name: Tesla
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Company where Ian Cleary worked after completing his master’s degree in Silicon Valley.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It illustrates Cleary’s post-assault trajectory, showing how he moved from a college campus to a high-profile tech industry role, raising concerns about accountability in professional environments.

namedEntities.name: France
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Country where Ian Cleary was detained in Metz on a vagrancy charge in April 2024, leading to his extradition to the U.S.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: France served as the location where Cleary was legally detained, enabling U.S. authorities to track and extradite him, marking a key turning point in the case.

namedEntities.name: Metz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: City in France where Ian Cleary was detained on a vagrancy charge in April 2024.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the specific location where Cleary was held before extradition, highlighting the international dimension of tracking fugitive offenders.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Ian Cleary was sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025 for sexually assaulting a college student, Shannon Keeler, at Gettysburg College in 2013. The case, long delayed due to prosecutorial reluctance, was revived when Keeler shared her experience in an Associated Press story in 2021. Cleary was extradited from France in 2024 after being detained on a vagrancy charge, and he pleaded guilty to second-degree sexual assault. Despite his remorse and history of mental illness, the judge, Kevin Hess, imposed a sentence below state guidelines, citing his admission of guilt and desire for atonement. The case highlights systemic failures in campus sexual assault investigations, including destroyed evidence and long delays in prosecution, and underscores the emotional toll on survivors. The message Cleary sent to Keeler saying 'So I raped you' re-opened trauma and symbolized the enduring impact of sexual violence and institutional neglect.
title: Man Sentenced in 2013 College Sexual Assault Case After Decade-Long Pursuit
